journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering

title-group.article-title: Steady fully developed mixed convection flow in a vertical parallel plate microchannel with bilateral heating and filled with porous material

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mathematics, Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria

author-notes.corresp: Deborah Daramola, Department of Mathematics, Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria. Email: debola32000@yahoo.com

abstract.p: This study investigated analytically the hydrodynamic and thermal behaviour of a fully developed laminar, viscous, incompressible fluid in a vertical parallel plate microchannel taking into account the velocity slip and thermal jump at the walls. The governing equations are expressed in a dimensionless form using the dimensionless quantities. The method of undetermined coefficient was employed to obtain the closed-form expression for velocity, which is used to determine the skin friction. The solution obtained is then presented graphically and the results are discussed for various dimensionless parameters entering the problem. During the course of investigation, it is found that the critical values of the mixed convection parameter Gre (which is the ratio of the Grashof number Gr to the Reynolds number Re) led to flow reversal decrease with increase in Darcy number, while it increases with increase in Knudsen number Kn. Also, the Nusselt number Nu is found to increase with increasing Darcy number.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The analysis of heat and mass transfer in porous media has been of great importance due to its increasing practical applications. Examples include packed-bed catalytic reactor, geothermal reservoirs, drying of porous solids, thermal insulation, petroleum resources and many others. Recently, we have noticed a remarkable progress in the field of micro-electro-mechanical-systems that encounter fluid flow in devices such as micro-pumps, micro-turbines and micro-robotics among others. A series of experimental as well as theoretical studies have been carried out in this area in order to understand the fluid behaviour within these micro-devices. Notable among the studies of transport phenomena in microchannel are the works of Ho and Tai,1 Palm,2 Sobhan and Garimella,3 Obot,4 Rostami et al.,5,6 Gad-el-Hak,7 Guo and Li8,9 and Morini.10 Aydin and Avci11–14 theoretically studied forced convective heat transfer in two different microgeometries, namely microtube and microduct between two parallel plates both for fully developed and developing cases. Chen and Weng15 analytically studied the fully developed natural convection in an open-ended vertical parallel plate microchannel with asymmetric wall temperature distribution in which the effect of rarefaction and fluid wall interaction were shown to increase the volume flow rate and decrease the heat transfer. The effect of the hyperbolic heat conduction model on the transient hydrodynamics and thermal behaviours of fluid flow in an open-ended vertical parallel plate microchannel was analytically studied by Khadrawi et al.16

There is free convective flow in the fluid as a result of the buoyancy forces generated by temperature differences. In a forced convective flow, the effect of the buoyancy forces is usually negligible. There are cases when these buoyancy forces have a significant influence on the flow and consequently on the heat and mass transfer rate. Such combined or mixed convection has been examined by many researchers as a heat transfer enhancement technique for channel cooling; for example, it is used mostly as a cooling device in microchips. Avci and Aydin17 investigated analytically the mixed convection flow of rarefied gas in a vertical, asymmetrically heated microchannel between two parallel plates and the effect of the mixed convection parameter number Gre, the Knudsen number Kn and the ratio of wall temperature difference rT on the microchannel hydrodynamic and thermal behaviours are determined. The objective of this study is to analytically investigate mixed convection of rarefied gas in a vertical, asymmetrically heated microchannel filled with porous material. Survey of literature suggests that this has not been given attention in the past. It is believed that the velocity field for the case under consideration will serve as a good estimate for engineer–designer. The governing equations are expressed in a dimensionless form using the dimensionless quantities. The method of undetermined coefficient was employed to obtain the closed form of the equation.

sec.title: Mathematical analysis
sec.p:
Consider hydrodynamically and thermally fully developed, steady laminar mixed convection flow having constant properties (i.e. thermal conductivity and thermal diffusivity of the fluid are considered to be independent of temperature). In this analysis, the following assumptions are used.
Fluid and porous material are in local thermal equilibrium.
All properties of fluid and porous material are constant except fluid density related to the buoyancy term.
Classical conservation equations successfully coupled with the corresponding wall boundary conditions (slip condition for the velocity and jump condition for the temperature) are adopted because the gas no longer reaches the velocity or temperature of the surface. Two main characteristics of micro-scale phenomena are the velocity slip and the temperature jump.
(1)us=-2-FFλ∂u∂y|y=W where us is the velocity slip, λ the molecular mean free path and F the tangential momentum accommodation coefficient. It should be noted that F ranges between 0 and 1. For a perfectly smooth surface at the molecular level, F→0. This is referred to as specular reflection and results in perfect slip at the boundary. However, when the surface is extremely rough, the molecules are reflected at totally random angles and lose all their tangential momentum; in this case F=1 and is referred to as diffusive reflection. In this study, we assume F is close to unity, which is the value for a typical engineering application.18 (2)Ts-Tw=-2-FtFt2γγ+1λPr∂T∂y|y=W where Ts is the temperature of the gas at the wall, Tw the wall temperature and Ft the thermal accommodation coefficient; for the rest of the analysis. F and Ft assumed to be 1. The fluid is bounded by a vertical plate at x=0 and x=1. All physical quantities except pressure will depend only on y. Assuming hydrodynamically and thermally fully developed flow, the transverse velocity ν becomes zero, then the continuity equation drops to ∂u/∂x=0. The Boussinesq’s approximation has been used in this study. It should be noted here that there are two separate groups in the existing literature on the consideration of density gradient in the fluid flow, though flows in microchannel are basically due to pressure gradient. However, situation arises where density gradient occurs in the fluid and this leads to setting up of convection current and hence the case becomes a mixed convection flow. For example, in the rarefied gas, Chen and Weng15 assumed that the Boussinesq’s approximation is valid. Ignoring viscous dissipation assuming a low-speed flow of a low Pr fluid and substituting the above condition into the governing equation of the heat and fluid flow, we obtain (3)uKν=-1ρdpdx+νeff∂2u∂y2±βg(T-T0) (4)u∂T∂x=[kp(ρcp)p]∂2T∂y2 The pressure P is thus measured related to that which would exist at the same elevation in the stagnant fluid if it were at a uniform temperature T0. The positive sign in front of the buoyancy term applies to the buoyancy-assisted flow and the negative one to the opposed flow (see Figure 1 below)19 (5)u=us1,T=Ts1 aty=0u=us2,T=Ts2 aty=W Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of the flow domain.

By introducing the following non-dimensional quantities (6)Y=yW,θ=T-T0T2-T0,U=uum,Kn=λW,βε=2-FF,βt=2-FtFt2γγ+11Pr,Da=ρKW2,X=xReW,P=pρu02,Gr=βg(T2-T0)W3ε2,Re=u0Wε,n=βg(T2-T0)W2εu0 equations (3) and (4) can be written as (7)UDa=-dPdX+d2UdY2+GrReθ (8)d2θdY2=0 In terms of the dimensionless variables defined in equation (6), boundary conditions given in equation (5) can be shown as (9)U=βεKndUdY, θ=Ts1-T0T2-T0=rT+βTKndθdY atY=0U=-βεKndUdY, θ=Ts2-T0T2-T0=1-βTKndθdY atY=1 (10)rT=T1-T0T2-T0

Equation (8) indicates that the dimensionless temperature varies linearly across the duct. Integrating equation (8) and applying the boundary conditions gives (11)θ=A0+A1Y where (12)A0=rT+βTKnA1andA1=1-rT1+2βTKn
The expression for temperature in equation (11) is the same as that of Avci and Aydin.17

Substituting equations (11) and (12) into the momentum equation (7) and solving it using the conditions (9) (13)U=Acosh(Y(Da)-1)+Bsinh(Y(Da)-1) -DaCY-DaD where (14)A=B(Da)-1βνKn +Da(GreA1Kn(βε-βT)+dPdX-Gre(rT))B=Da(Gre(rT)q3-dPdXq3-GreA1Kn(βν-βT)q1 -GreA1q4)q2C=-GreA1 and D=-GreA0+dPdX and (15)q1=cosh(Da)-1+(Da)-1βεKnsinh(Da)-1q2=(Da)-1(βεKn)2sinh(Da)-1 +2(Da)-1βεKncosh(Da)-1sinh(Da)-1q3=cosh(Da)-1 +(Da)-1βεKnsinh(Da)-1-1q4=1+βεKn+βTKn

At any cross section in the channel, conservation of mass gives (16)∫01UdY=1 Substituting equation (13) into equation (16) (17)dPdx=(Gre(rT)q5-GreKnA1(βε-βT)q6 -GreA1q7+q8)q5 where (18)q5=1-Da((Da)-1sinh(Da)-1) -q3q2(Da((Da)-1-(Da)-1cosh(Da)-1) -βεKnsinh(Da)-1)q6=-Da((Da)-1sinh(Da)-1) -q1q2(Da((Da)-1-(Da)-1cosh(Da)-1) -βεKnsinh(Da)-1)q7=-q4q2(Da((Da)-1-(Da)-1cosh(Da)-1) -βεKnsinh(Da)-1)q8=-C2+GreβTKnA1-(Da)-1 Substituting equations (17) and (18) into equation (13) gives (19)U=Acosh(Y(Da)-1)+Bsinh(Y(Da)-1) -Da(CY-GreA2+GreX0q5+q8q5) where (20)X0=rTq5-KnA1(βν-βT)q6-A1q7

The dimensionless mean/bulk temperature is defined as (21)θm=∫01UθdY∫01UdY Substituting equations (11), (19) and (20) into equation (21) gives (22)θm=Tm-T0T2-T0=Da(A0+A1) ×(Asinh(Da)-1+Bcosh(Da)-1) -Da(C(A02+A13)-D(A0+A12)) +DaA1A(1-cosh(Da)-1) -B(DaA0+Da(A1sinh(Da)-1))

The convective heat transfer coefficient is given as follows (23)h=-ka∂T∂y|y=WT2-Tm=-kaW∂θ∂Y|Y=11-θm which is obtained from the following Nusselt number (24)Nu=A11-([Da(A0+A1) ×(Asinh(Da)-1+Bcosh(Da)-1) -Da(CF2+DF3)+Xw]) where (25)Xw=Da((A1A)(1-cosh(Da)-1)-BF4) and (26)F2=(A02+A13)F3=A0+A12F4=A0(Da)-1+A1sinh(Da)-1

sec.title: Discussion of the results
sec.p: This study investigates the interactive effects of the mixed convection parameter Gre, the Knudsen number (Kn), the ratio of the wall temperature difference rT and the Darcy number (Da) on heat and fluid flow in a microchannel between two parallel plates with asymmetrical heating for both hydrodynamically and thermally fully developed cases. The Knudsen number (Kn) is the ratio of the gas mean free path (λ) to the characteristic dimension of the fluid flow region (W) and it determines the degree of rarefaction and the degree of the validity of the continuum approach. As Kn increases, rarefaction becomes more important and eventually the continuum approach breaks down. In this study, investigation is carried out with Knudsen number values in the range 0.001≤Kn≤0.1. (The slip flow regime) Also, the following values of mixed convection parameter-500≤Gre≤500. are used.17 In addition, the values of Da is taken between 10-3≤Da≤10-1,βε used is 1.0, while the value of βT is taken to be (1.666) and ratio of wall temperature difference (rT) is 0.5.

As first, we validated our analysis by taking large values of Da. The velocity distribution given in equation (19) is exactly identical to that given by Avci and Aydin.17 The limiting value of Gre for a flow reversal can be found by setting (27)(dUdY)Y=0=0 Applying this condition to equation (13), we obtain (28)Gre=β1β2+β3 (29)β1=-Da-3/2q3q5whereβ2=-(q1(Da)-1KnA1(βε-βT) +q4(Da)-1A1-A1q2)β3=q3A1(Da)-1q5(Kn(βε-βT)q6 -βTKn+q7-0.5) To examine the influence of these controlling parameters, the variations of temperature and velocity are presented in Figures 2 to 10. Figure 2.
Velocity profile for different Kn (Gre=100,βε=1andDa=0.1).
Figure 3.
Temperature profile for different Kn(Gre=100,βε=1andDa=0.1).

This shows the hydrodynamic response of the fluid to variation in Knudsen number. Increasing rarefaction increases the velocity slip on both walls. From this figure, it is observed that fluid velocity increases on both walls as Knudsen number Kn increases. This is due to the fact that as Kn increases, fluid interaction with the walls decreases, allowing for free motion of the fluid particles and hence increases in velocity near the walls. However, at the centre of the channel, it is observed that fluid velocity decreases as Kn increases. This is due to the fact that break in continuum reduces the effect of the pressure gradient on the fluid.

This shows the thermal response of the fluid to variation in Knudsen number. Increasing rarefaction increases the velocity slip on both walls. From this figure, it is observed that fluid temperature increases on the cold wall as Knudsen number Kn increases but decreases on the hot wall as Knudsen number Kn increases. This is due to the fact that as Kn increases, rarefaction increases and hence fluid interaction with the walls decreases.

In Figure 4, it is observed that velocity decreases as Darcy number Da increases near the cold wall. It is as a result of the effect of the large Gre on the Da. This causes the fluid to have a high tendency of a reverse flow as Da values increases. Though near the middle of the channel, the effect of Da is not felt, whereas near the hotter wall in the range 0.45≤y≤0.9 the velocity increases as Da increases. This is due to the fact that as Da increases, there is an increase in the free motion of the fluid, and hence, an increase in the fluid velocity. Figure 4.
Velocity profile for different Da(βε=1,Gre=0.1andKn=0.1).

Figure 5 depicts the velocity profile for different rT. It is observed that velocity increases with increase in rT on the cold wall, whereas near the hot wall, there is a decrease in velocity as rT increases. Figure 5.
Velocity profile for different rT (Kn=0.1,βε=1andDa=0.1).

In Figure 6, however, near the cold wall, increasing Gre leads to decrease in fluid velocity, whereas near the hot wall, increasing Gre leads to an increase in velocity. At the middle of the channel, the fluid flow is not affected by Gre. Physically speaking, increasing Gre>0 means convection current and pressure gradient support each other, hence an increase in fluid velocity. On the other hand, Gre<0 shows natural convection, opposing the effect of the pressure gradient. Figure 6.
Velocity profile for different Gre(Kn=0.1,βε=1andDa=0.1).

In Figure 7, it is observed that as the ratio of the temperature difference rt increases, the temperature on both walls; temperature gradient on the hot wall is higher than that of the cold wall. Figure 7.
Temperature profile for different rT (Kn=0.1,βε=1andDa=0.1).

Figure 8(a) and (b) shows that skin friction increases on both walls as Da increases. It decreases as the Knudsen number Kn increases on the cold wall; the effect is the reverse on the hot wall, as shown in Figure 8(b). Figure 8.
The variation of the skin friction with Kn at different values of Da at wall: (a) y=0 and (b) y=1.

In Figure 9, the effect of the Darcy number Da and the Knudsen number Kn on the Nusselt number is depicted. It is observed that an increase in Da leads to an increase in Nusselt number, but an increase in Kn reduces the Nusselt number. Figure 9.
The variation of the Nu with Kn at different values of r_\tau (a) and Da (b).

Figure 10(a) and (b) shows the combined effect of the Darcy number Da and mixed convection parameter Gre on the flow. It is observed that small values of Da reduces the effect of Gre so as to cause a reverse flow. Figure 10.
Variation of velocity with Gre and Da at: (a) y=0 and (b) y=1.

Table 1 presents the effect of Kn and Da on the critical values of Gre which signifies the onset of reverse flow near the wall y=0. Similar results but with opposite sign are the values Gre at the wall y=1. These tables clearly show that Gre decreases as Da increases due to the fact that with an increases in Da, porosity of the medium increases, and thus, it requires a reduced Gre to induce a reverse flow. On the other hand, the critical value of Gre increases with increases in fluid rarefaction. This is so because as Kn increases, molecular distance increases within the fluid; hence, it requires an increased Gre to induce a reverse flow. Table 1.
Critical values of Gre at the wall y=0.
Kn

In Figure 11(a) and (b), it is observed that there is a linear correlation between the Nusselt number Nu and the Knudsen number Kn while there is square correlation between the Nusselt number Nu and the Darcy number Da.Figure 11.
Correlation of Nusselt number Nu with Da and Kn (a, b).

In addition to justifying the physics of the problem, the results obtained herein are in excellent agreement with the published work of Avci and Aydin17 when Da is large (see Table 3). Experimental data are yet to be found to validate the formulation of this problem and the numerical procedure. It is hoped that a study such as this will encourage further work in this field. Table 3.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Flow and heat transfer characteristics of mixed convection in a parallel plate microchannel with uniform wall temperature has been presented. Velocity-slip and temperature-jump conditions are included in the analysis.

The effect of mixed convection parameter n, the Knudsen number Kn and the porous media Da on the heat and fluid flow phenomena have been shown with the aid of line graphs. It is observed that a growing porous media Da accelerates the flow velocity of the fluid. The skin friction is found to decrease as Kn or rT increases. The Nusselt number is found to decrease as Kn or rT increases, but increase as Da increases. However Da can be used to suppress the onset of the reverse flow.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
